studies.study_title: Cannabis Induces Clinical Remission in Crohn's Disease: Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Naftali T, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Dotan I, et al. 2013. Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology.
studies.title: Cannabis Induces Clinical Remission in Crohn's Disease: Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Naftali T, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Dotan I, et al.

outcomes.results: Cannabis: 45% remission vs Placebo: 10% (p=0.03); 90% clinical response (CDAI >100 point reduction) vs 40% placebo
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Quality of life improved; steroid-free remission in 5/11; sleep improved; pain reduced

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Landmark first RCT in Crohn's; 45% remission rate; high unmet need indication

studies.study_title: CBD for Crohn's Disease: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Naftali T, Mechulam R, Marii A, et al. 2017. Inflammatory Bowel Diseases.
studies.title: CBD for Crohn's Disease: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Naftali T, Mechulam R, Marii A, et al.

outcomes.results: CBD alone: 40% response vs Placebo: 30%; Not statistically significant (p=0.5); CBD-only insufficient at this dose
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Quality of life improved; CRP unchanged; suggests CBD-only needs higher doses or THC combination

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - CBD-only mechanism data; dose-response information; safety profile

studies.study_title: CBD-Rich Cannabis Oil for Crohn's Disease: Phase II Trial
studies.citation: Naftali T, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Almog S, et al. 2021. Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology.
studies.title: CBD-Rich Cannabis Oil for Crohn's Disease: Phase II Trial
studies.authors: Naftali T, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Almog S, et al.

outcomes.results: Cannabis oil: 65% remission vs Placebo: 35% (p=0.04); Significant CDAI reduction (mean -82 points)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Quality of life (IBDQ) improved 45%; CRP reduced 28%; fecal calprotectin reduced (inflammation marker)

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - CBD-rich formulation; objective inflammation markers; 65% remission; steroid-sparing

studies.study_title: Long-Term Cannabis Treatment in IBD: 12-Month Prospective Study
studies.citation: Lahat A, Lang A, Ben-Horin S. 2012. Digestion.
studies.title: Long-Term Cannabis Treatment in IBD: 12-Month Prospective Study
studies.authors: Lahat A, Lang A, Ben-Horin S

outcomes.primary_measure: Disease activity and quality of life over 12 months
outcomes.results: Harvey-Bradshaw Index reduced: 14.5→7.0 (p<0.001); 21 patients (70%) achieved clinical benefit
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Surgery reduced; hospitalizations reduced; quality of life improved 67%

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - 12-month long-term data; prospective design; surgery/hospitalization reduction

studies.study_title: Cannabis for Ulcerative Colitis: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.citation: Irving PM, Ber-Meir T, Badi A, et al. 2018. Journal of Crohn's and Colitis.
studies.title: Cannabis for Ulcerative Colitis: Randomized Controlled Trial
studies.authors: Irving PM, Ber-Meir T, Badi A, et al.

outcomes.results: Cannabis: 28% remission vs Placebo: 26%; Not significant for remission but 59% had clinical response
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Quality of life significantly improved (p<0.05); physician global assessment improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - UC indication (distinct from Crohn's); quality of life improvement; CBD-rich formulation

studies.study_title: Cannabis and Cannabinoids for IBD: Cochrane Systematic Review
studies.citation: Kafil TS, Nguyen TM, MacDonald JK, Chande N. 2018. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews.
studies.title: Cannabis and Cannabinoids for IBD: Cochrane Systematic Review
studies.authors: Kafil TS, Nguyen TM, MacDonald JK, Chande N

outcomes.results: Limited RCT data but promising signals; remission rates 40-45% vs 10-35% placebo in individual trials
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Consistent quality of life improvements; safety favorable; calls for larger trials

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Cochrane gold standard; identifies evidence gaps; confirms safety profile

studies.study_title: Cannabis Use and Hospitalization in Crohn's Disease: National Database Study
studies.citation: Mbachi C, Attar B, Wang Y, et al. 2019. Annals of Gastroenterology.
studies.title: Cannabis Use and Hospitalization in Crohn's Disease: National Database Study
studies.authors: Mbachi C, Attar B, Wang Y, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Hospitalization outcomes in cannabis users vs non-users
outcomes.results: Cannabis users: Lower bowel obstruction (3.9% vs 7.9%), fewer fistulas (2.1% vs 4.5%), shorter LOS (4.4 vs 5.7 days)
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Lower blood transfusion need; reduced colectomy rates (2.2% vs 3.8%); lower total charges

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Massive N=615,817; reduced complications; reduced surgery; healthcare utilization

studies.study_title: Low-Dose Naltrexone Plus CBD for Crohn's Disease
studies.citation: Smith JP, Field D, Bingaman SI, et al. 2013. Digestive Diseases and Sciences.
studies.title: Low-Dose Naltrexone Plus CBD for Crohn's Disease
studies.authors: Smith JP, Field D, Bingaman SI, et al.

outcomes.results: Combination: 75% response vs Placebo: 38% (p<0.01); 50% achieved remission
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Endoscopic improvement in 60%; CRP reduced 34%; quality of life improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Novel combination therapy; endoscopic improvement; NIH-funded

studies.study_title: Medical Cannabis Registry: IBD Outcomes in 127 Patients
studies.citation: Bar-Lev Schleider L, Mechoulam R, Saban N, et al. 2019. European Journal of Gastroenterology and Hepatology.
studies.title: Medical Cannabis Registry: IBD Outcomes in 127 Patients
studies.authors: Bar-Lev Schleider L, Mechoulam R, Saban N, et al.
studies.journal: European Journal of Gastroenterology and Hepatology

outcomes.primary_measure: Quality of life and symptom improvement
outcomes.results: Overall improvement: 79%; Social function: +67%; Work ability: +56%; Pain: -92%; Sleep: +67%
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Steroid use reduced 44%; 5-ASA reduced 22%; anti-TNF reduced 18%

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - 44-month mean follow-up; medication reduction data; largest IBD cannabis registry

studies.study_title: Nabiximols for Abdominal Pain in Crohn's Disease
studies.citation: Irving PM, Whelan K, Kaplan GG. 2020. Alimentary Pharmacology and Therapeutics.
studies.title: Nabiximols for Abdominal Pain in Crohn's Disease
studies.authors: Irving PM, Whelan K, Kaplan GG
studies.sample_size: 48 Crohn's patients with persistent abdominal pain

outcomes.results: Nabiximols: 58% pain reduction vs Placebo: 31% (p<0.05); 67% achieved ≥30% pain reduction
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Quality of life improved 44%; anxiety reduced; sleep improved; disease activity stable

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Pain-focused endpoint; FDA-pathway drug; functional symptom improvement

studies.study_title: Endocannabinoid System in IBD: Therapeutic Target Review
studies.citation: Storr MA, Yüce B, Andrews CN, Sharkey KA. 2015. Nature Reviews Gastroenterology and Hepatology.
studies.title: Endocannabinoid System in IBD: Therapeutic Target Review
studies.authors: Storr MA, Yüce B, Andrews CN, Sharkey KA

outcomes.primary_measure: Mechanistic rationale for cannabinoid therapy in IBD
outcomes.results: CB1/CB2 receptor upregulation in inflamed mucosa; Anti-inflammatory: TNF-α↓, IL-1β↓, IL-6↓; Gut motility regulation; Epithelial barrier protection
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: FAAH inhibition potential; 2-AG and anandamide role; microbiome interactions

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Nature Reviews; mechanistic rationale; therapeutic target validation

studies.study_title: Cannabis and Need for Surgery in Crohn's Disease: Retrospective Analysis
studies.citation: Naftali T, Mechulam R, Lev LB, Konikoff FM. 2014. Alimentary Pharmacology and Therapeutics.
studies.title: Cannabis and Need for Surgery in Crohn's Disease: Retrospective Analysis
studies.authors: Naftali T, Mechulam R, Lev LB, Konikoff FM

outcomes.results: Cannabis users: 23% surgery vs Non-users: 42% surgery (p<0.05); NNT = 5 to prevent one surgery
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Hospitalization rate: 14% vs 29%; steroid courses reduced

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Surgery prevention data; cost-effectiveness implications; 3-year follow-up

studies.study_title: European Crohn's and Colitis Organisation Position Statement on Cannabis
studies.citation: Torres J, Caprioli F, Katsanos KH, et al. 2020. Journal of Crohn's and Colitis.
studies.title: European Crohn's and Colitis Organisation Position Statement on Cannabis
studies.authors: Torres J, Caprioli F, Katsanos KH, et al.

outcomes.primary_measure: Clinical guidance for cannabis in IBD
outcomes.results: Evidence level: Moderate for symptom improvement; Insufficient for remission induction; Safe as adjunct therapy; Need for standardized formulations
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Calls for larger RCTs; monitoring recommendations; contraindication guidance

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - European professional gastroenterology society endorsement; establishes clinical role

studies.study_title: CBD-Rich Cannabis for Perianal Crohn's Disease
studies.citation: Naftali T, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Konikoff FM. 2022. Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research.
studies.title: CBD-Rich Cannabis for Perianal Crohn's Disease
studies.authors: Naftali T, Bar-Lev Schleider L, Konikoff FM

outcomes.results: Cannabis: 53% fistula improvement vs Placebo: 19% (p=0.02); 25% complete fistula closure
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: Pain reduced 62%; drainage reduced; quality of life improved

studies.regulatory_relevance: CRITICAL - Perianal disease indication (severe complication); fistula closure data; unmet need

studies.study_title: Pediatric IBD and Medical Cannabis: Safety and Efficacy Study
studies.citation: Hoffenberg EJ, McWilliams S, Mikulich-Gilbertson SK, et al. 2019. Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition.
studies.title: Pediatric IBD and Medical Cannabis: Safety and Efficacy Study
studies.authors: Hoffenberg EJ, McWilliams S, Mikulich-Gilbertson SK, et al.
studies.journal: Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition

outcomes.primary_measure: Symptom improvement and safety in pediatric population
outcomes.results: 78% reported symptom improvement; abdominal pain reduced 65%; disease activity scores improved
outcomes.secondary_outcomes: School attendance improved; weight gain; no growth concerns

safety.adverse_events: Mild fatigue (22%), mood changes (9% - all positive)

studies.regulatory_relevance: HIGH - Pediatric IBD population; safety profile in children; growth data
